content.description: Nice fingercrack in a corner. VERY popular. DANGER: There is a very large flake/block just below the top(see photo)which looks like it could drop at any time. If it happens when someone is climbing or standing near the base it would be deadly.

Right of Reuben's Brother is this short, 3 bolt lead. Climb right of the chimney until it's possible to gingerly step left at the first bolt. Climb the pocketed face to a crux just before the chains. Good route, but a perpetual dirtfest as it follows a fairly active water streak.
content.protection: Bolts(the first one is high), to chains.

content.description: This is a good, albeit dirty at the start, route. Probably the best beginners lead on the Rims. Easy climbing leads to a step right and a finish on the obvious knobs.
content.location: Right of Assassin and left of Billings Radio.

content.description: Once an obscure, rarely done route, the addition of bolts and chains increased its popularity astronomically. Despite having taken a beating from heavy traffic, water, and gastronomically challenged birds in recent years, it's still worth a visit. A tricky start leads to easy climbing and a bouldery crux. Named after a tree that used to reside on the route but has since departed. The "direct start" is 11a/b.

Start at Welcome to Billings, follow the flake left (or do the 2 move "direct start"), flash a few bouldery moves, cruise to a "tenacious" upper crux, step left, don't slip and you own it. Easier for tall folks, harder for not so tall folks. Good sustained climbing.

DANGER: There is a large flake/block at the top of Welcome to Billings which looks like it could drop at any time; if someone were standing near the base it would be deadly.
content.protection: Bolts, chain lead anchors, eyebolts for TR anchors. Finish straight up or take a couple steps left after the last bolt to some layback moves(better). These moves are fairly easy but a slip at this point while leading would be uncomfortable. You may want to long sling the left TR anchor to protect them.

content.description: Climb the buttress right of Excuse Abuse with some questionable rock and even more questionable bolting. Good bouldery crux toward the top. Finish directly up the shallow crack or step right to the large pocket(easier). Tricky hard.
content.protection: Bolts, the first is very high and very off route to the left.  Eyebolts.

content.description: Start beneath the large huecos about 20' left of Elephant's Slipper on the corner. Solve the start which may involve a big reach, fire the huecos, traverse right onto the steep face left of Elephant Slipper, straight up with a big move, step left, pull a few thin slab moves and tick this sucker off!
content.protection: Long slings for TR. The bolts are in line with the upper crux so if you fall at the start you'll be dragged through the dirt and bushes which probably won't kill you but it won't be a whole lot of fun either. Would benefit from a directional bolt to prevent this.

content.description: One of the easier routes. Faces west for early shade. Usually sandy at the top, not a good choice to solo.

Walk Up offers one of the easiest technical routes to the top of the Rims and as such has been the scene of several fiascos and near disasters. Please be aware of and do not disturb or harrass the pigeons if they should be roosting just below the top. A good beginners route.

Located on a boulder below Decade of Decay, etc. is this diminutive testpiece. Nice south east facing fingercrack that has been bouldered but it is possible(with creativity) to rig a toprope. The west side also has an interesting looking crack. Rarely done, will need cleaning.
content.protection: Long slings or 2nd rope for TR.

content.description: Squeezed between BeBop Deluxe and Center Face is this challenging and sustained line of small holds. Start in a thin seam just left of Center Face. Join BBD after a few moves. Continue straight up over the bulge via a very long move to a LH razor pinch and another long RH move to a shallow 2f pocket(crux). Continue up and left to a good flake(BBD), step right and up to a topout independant of CF and BBD. Very good climbing. Borrows LH holds from BBD but avoids the hand holds on Center Face. Keep your hands and feet to the left of the bolt line and you’re good. If it feels easier than 12c, you cheated or maybe you're just that good.
content.protection: It may be possible, but far from ideal, to lead this using/rigging the bolts on Center Face.

content.description: Climb the wide slot to a nice thin hands section.
content.protection: Gear, very long and small chains.

content.description: Layback to cruxy face.
Great face climbing on small holds. Turn the corner at 2/3 height and tackle the triangular face on good holds. A jam or two and it's a "send".
content.protection: Bolts, chained anchors; there are both TR and sport anchors.

content.description: Right of Assassin is this wide crack thing that sometimes gets done but not by me. Shares the start with Unknown Sport but heads up and left to finish.
Easily climb to the obviously manufactured holds and a slick bouldery crux. Sustained climbing on edges leads to easier climbing at 3/4 height. The start of this route is in rough shape.
West facing pocketed face just right of Reuben. Climb the muddy corner or the arete to the left (.11a TR) to a no hands rest. Positive holds lead to a bouldery crux with a big move. Sporty lead.
Corner crack about 50' left of Faster Pussycat and just right of Flakes a Lot. Starts thin and widens toward the top(crux). Popular. Named after a sandwich.
When you've climbed every other route, there's always this one! Really not as bad as it looks, which is good. Decaying slab to nice crack.

A great route that never gets climbed the “right” way. Start In the chimney to the left of the thin flake and in front of a slabby block. Step up onto the block (~3 feet) and stem right (do NOT climb 10-15' up the chimney in spite of what is written elsewhere, and do not reach the ledge between the first and second bolts with your feet still on the block) to reach the very base of the flake (below the first bolt) with your right hand. Climb the face of the flake, avoiding the wall to the left (not even once!) and treading lightly at the hollow and fractured flake just below the top. A direct start to the flake has been done with the same overall grade.
content.protection: Bolts. Bolt anchors which may be difficult (dangerous) to access.

content.description: Nice slabby 5.9 face climb. Good warmup and intro to rims climbing. Danger: There is a large block above the anchors which looks like it could roll/drop sometime soon. Barney/Betty Rubble also present rockfall potential/danger.
content.protection: Bolts. Chained anchors which need to be replaced.

content.description: About 8 feet Left of Walkup is a pocketed water streak which keeps getting harder as holds break. Climb straight up past the pocketed knob(crux) avoiding any big holds to the right(The Horse Pasture) and continue up the lichen encrusted slab. If it seems easier than .11 you cheated.
content.protection: Dangerous junk anchors, back them up!

content.description: Located between Rockchuck Arete and Full Sail, this excellent climb offers interesting moves on steep and solid rock. It starts immediately right of RCA and ends at a small ledge ~10' from the top. A little spicy between the 3rd and 4th bolts.
Just like bitd.
content.protection: Big stuff. Long pants and sleeves to fend off the poison ivy.

climbs.name: Next to the Last Best Route in Billings

content.description: Around the corner west from Last Best. Faces east and gets evening shade. Easy crack (bolted) to steep crimpy face. Top it out just for fun.
content.protection: Bolts. The crux bolt (2nd to the last protection bolt) may be difficult for anyone under 6' to reach from the obvious clipping hold You may want to prehang it with an extended draw. Sport anchors. Eyebolts on top for TR anchor.

content.description: Unrepeated. Your troubles begin as soon as your feet leave the ground. Sustained climbing on frustratingly small holds with a long reach or two which may(or may not)be hard to avoid. Start at the beginning of a trough formed by a huge flake(which is off). Old Age(12b)starts from the top of the flake. At least it's short.
content.protection: 2 bolts for TR anchor. May want a crash pad to protect your back when you fall off the start.

content.description: Follow an easy hand crack to a thin crack with pin scars(crux). Finish straight up or step right(bolt) to finish on The Bishop.
content.protection: Gear, tree anchor or eyebolts (The Bishop).

content.description: Unrepeated. Continuously difficult face climbing. Start in the trough formed by a large flake(which is off) at a small, black, rounded shallow corner. Head up and left aiming for the bottom of the right arching feature. Continue straight up to a good hold below a small overhang. From there, follow the seam up and left, eventually cutting back right and up to finish. The best route in Billings if the holds are still there.
Good warmup for K2.
content.protection: Gear, very long and small chains

content.description: An interesting climb using thin crack and face moves but marred by rockfall potential.
content.location: Located just west(left) around the corner from Nasty Vicar in the vicinity of the enormous guillotine like corner flake. This is the furthest route left of the 3 bolted routes.

content.description: Rarely done. Start just right of a boulder blocking the trail 10' left of Dragonfly and just below some orange lichen. Head up and left eventually gaining the orange sloper. The crux is from here to the top.  Would benefit from a major cleaning and restoration effort.
content.protection: Long slings to sling the boulder.

content.description: Start about 10 feet right (not "just right") of Easy Street at the right edge of the bushes. Easy but somewhat dirty climbing leads to a step left and some tweaky moves. Head straight up with a big step left to the obvious feature, a long reach or not (crux), a no hands rest and a thin finishing slab move. Go ahead, you'll love it...to death.
I was told bitd this is 5.9 going to the right (Rockchuck Arete) and .10? to the left, but honestly I've never done it and don't know anybody who has in the past 40 years.

climbs.name: Last Best aka The Last Best Route in Billings

content.description: Start at some thin cracks ~50' right of Excuse Abuse and just left of the corner. Step right around the corner at half height onto the pocketed face. Sustained. A broken hold near the top may present a problem.
Need a good backscratch? Like to clip bolts? Like chimneys? Well if you do, you're an odd one but here's the route for you.
content.location: Left(west) of Center Face is the access chimney. Climb its' outer edge.

content.description: ...but only if you're 6'4" and like to dyno.

Start on small holds on a dark rib just left of C of I. Climb up avoiding all those nice holds off to the right(C of I) with a big move (crux) to a scoop down and right of the first bolt. Bear left, avoiding C of I until the final slab. It is also possible to climb C of I to the second bolt, step left and finish on Inconceivable (10a). If it seems easier than 11a, you need to go back and do it the right way.
content.protection: Bolts, stick clip with a very long stick.It is possible, but not ideal, to use the first bolt on  C of I(preclip)but don’t blow the second(first bolt on I). Shares chained anchors with C of I.

content.description: Neither should you. Start around the corner right from Mountaineer's Route. Head up and right with a cut back left at a small tree.
Climb the black water streak just right of Cliffs of Insanity. Steep climbing on pockets with a tricky crux bulge  to thin slab.
content.protection: Bolts, the 4th clip (crux) may present an unwanted challenge, you may want to prehang it with an extended draw. Bolted and chained anchor.

content.description: The Horse Pasture was Gregory's origional name. Follow large holds just left of Walkup looking for a move involving a large pocket, a knob and thin feet at about half height.
content.protection: Dangerous junk anchors, back them up!

content.description: AKA Born to Climb. Ugly name, ugly route with some ugly rope scars. Use longer slings and don’t lower directly off the anchors.
content.protection: Shares chains with Born to Hang.

content.description: Steep slab/face climbing. Start immediately right of Welcome to Billings and climb the faint buttress on very small holds avoiding the crack of WTB. Harder (and better!) than it looks. DANGER: There is a large flake/block at the top of WtB which looks like it could drop at any moment.
The crux will be much more difficult for anyone with large fingers (me).
Despite its diminutive lenghth, The Gem offers great sustained bouldery moves up a crackless corner with crimps, sidepulls and stems.
content.protection: Bolt anchors, which are dangerous to access.

content.description: Project. Start at the obvious flake and climb the gently overhanging arete on small sloping pockets and edges. Somebody please climb this. 13a?
The dirty holds at the start may make this seem harder than 5.9. Worth doing at the very least to check out those bodacious huecos.
FS once an area testpiece, now retains little of its' character due in part to a 30' block which has fractured and is in the process of slipping/falling.
Start left of Reuben and just right of D of D. Climb past the small overhang (reachy, bouldery crux) and continue with sustained climbing.
content.protection: Bolts, shares first one with Decade of Decay. If leading, keep in mind that the second (crux) bolt will be the only thing between you and the ground. Chains.

content.description: Follow Fat Cat but step right to do the direct finish on Faster Pussycat.

A great route that's unjustly ignored. Combines 2 routes. Follow Faster Pussycat to the obvious flake, step left to the upper section of The Cat's Meow and a bouldery crux sequence. Follow the light blue streak to another cruxy move near the top.
content.protection: Bolts. The crux bolt can't be reached from the obvious clipping stance and the one after that is off to the left (by necessity) and nothing after that until the top.

content.description: Great climb with a little bit of everything. Traverse right at the fingertip ledge at 3/4 height for 11a/b. The "direct finish," which is 11c TR, steps left, does the upper crux of Fat Cat, and then steps back right to finish on FP.
content.protection: Bolts and a couple small pieces if you choose to skip the retrobolted crack. For some reason there are 2 sets of anchors, go for the upper set of anchors(chains)for the full experience.

content.description: The crack in the chimney to the left of Psychotic Reaction has been climbed. FA bitd by some crazed glory seeker.
Face climb right down low when things get thin for .10c/d R and there will be no excuses for skipping the last 6' to the anchors.
Obscure.  Approach from Tree Route or go direct.
Begin by climbing Elephant's Slipper but continue straight up at the slot. Please consider rappelling vs lowering to prevent further rope/rock damage created by peoople who obviously didn't care.

Nice hand to finger crack. Bear left at the slot. Please consider rappelling vs lowering to prevent further rope/rock damage created by peoople who obviously didn't care as much as you should. The overhang at the top is a rockfall hazard.

Obscure but worth doing. Approx. 50' around the corner east of Excuse Abuse and just right of the route Slabarrific is a giant flake leaning against a south facing small face. EP starts at the top of the flake and climbs straight up a very shallow corner and water streak. Top it out for full value. A broken hold or 2 has upped the grade. Bouldery.
content.protection: Chained anchors, use caution when approaching.

content.description: Considered a sandbag at 5.9 probably due to its tricky crux. The obvious left leaning crack ~20' left of Assassin.
Start beneath the obvious west facing huecos. Easy climbing (not counting the first move) leads to cruxy moves with some bad rock. Needs a major cleaning and restoration.
content.protection: Long slings to sling the boulder.

content.description: Located behind some bushes (bring clippers), just left of a chimney between Cliffs of Insanity and Nasty Vicar. Good cruxy climbing down low on good rock, continue straight up, with a step right just below some obvious pockets to a flake system. Follow some dirty, but easy, moves to the top.
content.protection: 2 bolts for TR anchor, about 10' back (bring long slings).

content.description: If it weren't for some marginal "rock", this would be a great route. While the crux is on good rock there is some hollow, sandy and slippery stuff to be found. The overhang 6 feet below the anchors presents a significant rockfall danger.
This was a good route bitd. Unfortunately the top has fallen down(note nearby boulders) leaving a route of dubious quality.
content.location: West facing wall in the Center Face alcove. Leftmost route. Starts in a shallow corner and finishes on a white slab and fallen tree.

content.description: Climb the arete left of Prime Rib ecventually joining it at half height.
Shares the start with Flakes a Lot. Head left then straight up following obvious pockets, etc. on some very hollow(!!!) rock to a cruxy finish.
content.protection: Bolts, the 2nd from last is difficult to clip from the obvious clipping hold and the last has an aging draw that needs to go. Chained anchors.

content.description: Climb Pickpocket to the knob, step left to check out the hueco, straight up past the lichen encrusted slab to an astonishing finish.
Located left of Walk Up and right of Elephant Slipper. Chipped(PLEASE don't do this) and ugly but entertaining.  Becoming increasingly more difficult as holds break or fall off.
A chipped monstrosity...but fun. A key foothold has recently departed changing things considerably.

Sustained climbing on very small holds which may or may not still exist. Start just left of Assassin and avoid it until the obvious knob (knob only) at 3/4 height. Continue with a big move up and left, eventually stepping right to finish on Assassin. See photo for ticked hold route beta. Will need a good cleaning....but not too good!
Steep (for Billings) climbing on good holds, if you can find them.
content.protection: Bolts. The third bolt is(still) in a bad place. Bolts with chains, use the lower set, the upper set are dangerous junk on a detached block.

content.description: Yup, it's a chimney alright. Danger; There are some large blocks above this route which are ready to roll/drop.
Center Face has taken a hit from heavy rains in the past few years but seems to be cleaning up its’ act somewhat. Great sustained climbing.
Start on Sapsucker but head out left on small pockets and then head straight up. Will need cleaning as it's never climbed.
Decent crack climb with an obvious crux.
A couple broken (honestly, they just fell off) holds have upped the grade more than considerably, but don't let that intimidate you. .12++?
content.protection: Tree, use long slings or 2nd rope.

content.description: Obscure. Located between Billings Radio and The Gem. A bulgy start on dark rock leads to easier climbing past a small tree to the top.
content.protection: Tree for tr anchor, may need a directional.

content.description: Pumpy with a big move or two.
This is a very good face, pocket and arete climb. Using the wall to the right of the crack/corner (Gruntarrific / Born to Climb) with hands or feet lowers the grade.
content.protection: Bolts, shares anchors with Gruntarrific. Use long slings to avoid adding to the rock scars.
content.location: East end, faces east gets afternoon and evening shade.

content.description: Climb Mountaineer's Route for about 15 ' until it's possible to step/turn right to climb the colored face.
content.protection: Some creativity involved for TR anchors.

content.description: Climb Roof Right to the top of the flake, traverse left under the big roof, turn the corner and finish on Betty Rubble. Danger: one day this roof will fall.
Good jamming to stem or offwidth. You know you love it!
Follow Nasty Vicar to the ledge, step right and follow thin flakes to a cruxy move near the bolt.

Sustained climbing. Start at a flake in the chimney to the left of the pillar. Using the flake, immediately gain the face of the pillar. Climb a few difficult moves over a small overlap and follow the corner past some sugary rock to a step left and a good 2 handed knob.
content.protection: Bolted anchor. Please extend the anchor to below the rock scars (as in photo) to avoid making them worse.

content.description: Rarely done. Boulder the overhang, traverse right and climb the licheny slab to a perplexing and difficult headwall.

Nice hand to finger crack marred by rockfall potential. DANGER: The large block in the corner that forms the overhang that you climb under and over will fall someday, part of it already has. There is also a block above Prime Rib ready to drop.

Just left of Center Face. Good intro to the other hard routes on this wall. Start at the right half pad mono and step left at half height to skirt the bulge to the left. Great face climbing on small holds. Top it out for the full grade. Don't miss it!
Follow a corner crack to a small roof, bear left and continue up. The large block in the corner is a rockfall danger. There is also a block above Prime Rib ready to drop.
Located in the alcove about 200 yards west(left) of Center Face. Broken crack/face to crux moves over a bulge. Interesting moves on steep rock. Recent(3/20) rockfall has affected the start.
content.protection: Gear for the initial crack, bolts and bolt anchors which all need to be replaced. If toproping, extend slings to below the rock scars to prevent further damage.
